<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest
	income decreased to $44&nbsp;million when compared to the same period of 2014, as a result of lower cash investments in Brazil and Argentina and $12&nbsp;million of
	accumulated interest on a loan provided to and repaid by a related party in 2014. Interest expense decreased by 26% compared to last year, primarily due to lower average outstanding debt, mainly as a
	result of reduced working capital requirements due to lower global commodity prices in 2015 and interest charges of $65&nbsp;million related to certain ICMS tax credits in Brazil.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Income Tax Expense
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#151;In 2015, income tax expense from continuing operations increased to $296&nbsp;million from $249&nbsp;million in 2014 and the
	effective tax rate in 2015 decreased to 28% compared to 34% in 2014. Income tax expenses in 2015 included net tax charges of $16&nbsp;million that resulted primarily from the establishment of income
	tax valuation allowances in Asia-Pacific partially offset by the release of income tax valuation allowances in North America. The lower effective tax rate for 2015 resulted mainly from geographical
	earnings mix and valuation allowance movements.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	Discontinued Operations
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#151;Discontinued operations results in 2015 were income of $35&nbsp;million, net of tax, compared to
	income of $32&nbsp;million, net of tax, in 2014. Results in 2015, included gains in Brazilian fertilizer driven by foreign exchange gains and the recovery of previously written-off farmer
	receivables, which were partly offset by losses in our asset management business. Results in 2014 included benefits related to a tax amnesty program in Brazil and collections of previously written-off
	farmer receivables.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net Income Attributable to Bunge
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#151;Net income attributable to Bunge for 2015 was $791&nbsp;million compared to $515&nbsp;million for 2014. The
	increase in total segment EBIT of $292&nbsp;million discussed above and reduced net interest cost of $45&nbsp;million driven by lower average borrowings during the year was partially offset by the
	higher income tax expense ($296&nbsp;million in 2015 compared with $249&nbsp;million in 2014) on the higher income from continuing operations, before taxes.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	43
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=1,SEQ=44,EFW="2227431",CP="BUNGE LIMITED",DN="1",CHK=31810,FOLIO='43',FILE='DISK134:[15ZCW1.15ZCW15401]DM15401A.;17',USER='WWASSER',CD='24-FEB-2016;18:03' -->
<A NAME="A2227431Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DM15401_1_44">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2227431Z10-K_HTM_BG15401A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<UL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	2014 Compared to 2013
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
</UL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Agribusiness Segment
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#151;Agribusiness segment net sales decreased 8% to $42.1&nbsp;billion in 2014 compared to $45.5&nbsp;billion in 2013. Volumes
	were 1% higher in the year with increased volumes of grain origination in Europe resulting from good crops and harvest pace in the Black Sea region being offset by lower oilseeds distribution volumes
	in Asia-Pacific and processing in China and Argentina. Global commodity prices were generally lower in the year; especially corn prices, which declined significantly in the first nine months of the
	year and were on average 28% lower in 2014 compared to 2013. The impact of lower commodity prices on net sales was partly offset by the higher value mix of commodities sold in 2014 when compared with
	2013.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cost
	of goods sold also decreased by 8% to $40.4&nbsp;billion in 2014, compared with $43.7&nbsp;billion last year as a result of lower average commodity prices in 2014 and lower
	results from trading and our risk
	management strategies. These reductions were only partly offset by the 1% volume increase and higher value sales mix.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gross
	profit was $1,742&nbsp;million in 2014, 3% lower than $1,797&nbsp;million a year ago, primarily as losses in our Asia-Pacific oilseed processing operations, mainly in China,
	resulting from low structural margins in the region, and reduced trading and risk management results and approximately $80&nbsp;million of unrealized mark-to-market impacts related to North American
	processing and bunker fuel hedges at year end that are expected to reverse in 2014. These reductions more than offset good margins in North and South America, Central Europe and our oilseed
	distribution activities to the Middle East.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;SG&amp;A
	expenses were $875&nbsp;million in 2014 compared to $836&nbsp;million in 2013. In 2014, SG&amp;A expenses included costs from our new Terfron port facility in Northern Brazil and
	higher employee related costs and, to a lesser extent, higher bad debt expenses. SG&amp;A benefitted from weaker currencies when local currency costs were translated into U.S. dollars, partially
	offsetting the expense increases.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Noncontrolling
	interests represent (income) loss attributed to the noncontrolling interest holders in joint venture operations that are consolidated in our financial statements. In 2014,
	$23&nbsp;million of income compared to losses of $31&nbsp;million in 2013. Improved performance in our joint venture activities was primarily driven by our U.S. Pacific Northwest port operation
	and oilseed and biodiesel production ventures in Europe.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Segment
	EBIT decreased to $890&nbsp;million in 2014 from $1,032&nbsp;million in 2013, primarily due to lower gross profit, higher SG&amp;A and approximately $80&nbsp;million of
	mark-to-market impacts incurred in the fourth quarter, which are expected to reverse during 2014. EBIT for 2013 included a $16&nbsp;million gain from the sale of certain legal claims in Brazil.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Edible Oil Products Segment
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#151;Edible Oil Products segment net sales were $8&nbsp;billion in 2014 compared to $9.2&nbsp;billion in 2013. The lower
	net sales in 2014 were primarily a result of lower average commodity prices in 2014. Volumes decreased by 2% driven by rail logistics issues and soft demand from food processors in North America, and
	by lower retail demand and implementation of price management strategies in Brazil. Volumes were positively impacted in Argentina by export sales of bulk oil and in Asia-Pacific with strong volume
	growth across all our brands and our bakery fats business in India.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cost
	of goods sold decreased 14% to $7.4&nbsp;billion in 2014 from $8.6&nbsp;billion in 2013, primarily due to lower raw material costs resulting from lower global commodity prices
	and sales volumes.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gross
	profit in 2014 increased to $548&nbsp;million from $540&nbsp;million in 2013, primarily due to higher margins in Brazil, driven by a tight supply environment and an increased
	focus on operational improvements and price management strategies, and in Argentina, driven by higher export volumes within South America. Margins in North America were essentially flat, with higher
	margins in U.S.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	44
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=2,SEQ=45,EFW="2227431",CP="BUNGE LIMITED",DN="1",CHK=842902,FOLIO='44',FILE='DISK134:[15ZCW1.15ZCW15401]DM15401A.;17',USER='WWASSER',CD='24-FEB-2016;18:03' -->
<A NAME="A2227431Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DM15401_1_45">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2227431Z10-K_HTM_BG15401A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	packaged
	oils driven by operational improvement programs, partially offset by lower margins in refined oils on weaker export demand, rail logistics issues and, to a lesser extent, higher energy costs
	in the first quarter due to severe weather conditions in Canada.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;SG&amp;A
	Expenses increased to $482&nbsp;million in 2014 from $384&nbsp;million in 2013; SG&amp;A for 2014 included $98&nbsp;million expenses on certain ICMS tax credits in Brazil.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Segment
	EBIT decreased to $58&nbsp;million in 2014 from $163&nbsp;million in 2013 as a result of factors noted above. Segment EBIT for 2013 included a gain of $9&nbsp;million from
	the sale of certain legal claims in Brazil.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Milling Products Segment
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#151;Milling Products segment net sales were $2,064&nbsp;million in 2014, compared to $2,012&nbsp;million in 2013. Volumes
	increased by 12% primarily due to contributions from a wheat milling business in Mexico, which we acquired in December 2013. This increase was partly offset by lower volumes in our wheat milling
	business in Brazil, primarily due to our strategy to strengthen margins. The net increase in volumes was offset by lower average selling prices for corn and wheat products driven by lower average
	global commodity market prices relative to last year and by the impact of a weaker Brazilian
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	real
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	and Mexican
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	peso
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	when translated into U.S. dollars
	compared to 2013.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cost
	of goods sold was essentially flat with $1,753&nbsp;million and $1,750&nbsp;million for the years 2014 and 2013, respectively. The impact of the inclusion of the acquired wheat
	milling business in Mexico and higher prices for rice origination in the United States resulting from drought and water shortage was offset by lower prices for corn and wheat compared to the same
	period last year.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gross
	profit increased by 19% to $311&nbsp;million in 2014 from $262&nbsp;million in 2013, primarily as a result of inclusion of our Mexican wheat milling business acquired in
	December 2013 and the related synergies with our existing wheat milling business in Mexico. In addition, margins were higher in Brazil resulting
	from the implementation of price management strategies. In our U.S. milling operations, gross profit declined with lower margins in corn milling only partly offset by stronger margins in rice milling.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;SG&amp;A
	expenses increased by $29&nbsp;million to $168&nbsp;million in 2014 from $139&nbsp;million in 2013, primarily resulting from inclusion of our wheat milling business acquired
	in Mexico at the end of last year and $14&nbsp;million expenses on certain ICMS tax credits in Brazil, partially offset by the benefits of cost reduction initiatives and the impact of the weaker
	Brazilian
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	real
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	and Mexican
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	peso
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	on the translation of local currency expenses to the U.S. dollar.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Segment
	EBIT increased by 5% to $131&nbsp;million in 2014 from $125&nbsp;million in the same period a year ago, driven by the inclusion of our acquired wheat milling operations in
	Mexico and solid performance in Brazil wheat milling and U.S. rice milling, partly offset by higher SG&amp;A expenses, lower results in U.S. corn milling and foreign exchange losses in Mexico driven by a
	strong devaluation of the Mexican
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	peso
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	in the fourth quarter. Segment EBIT for 2013 included a gain of $6&nbsp;million from the sale of certain legal
	claims in Brazil.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Sugar and Bioenergy Segment
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#151;Sugar and Bioenergy segment net sales increased 8% to $4.5&nbsp;billion in 2014 compared to $4.2&nbsp;billion in 2013,
	as a result of higher sugarcane milling volumes and energy sales in Brazil. These increases were partly offset by a 6% decline in volumes, primarily in our trading and merchandising business. Average
	ethanol and energy prices in Brazil were higher compared to 2013, while average prices of sugar were lower. In our biofuels business, lower volumes were more than offset by higher U.S. corn ethanol
	prices.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cost
	of goods sold increased to $4.6&nbsp;billion in 2014 from $4.1&nbsp;billion in 2013. Higher costs of purchased sugarcane were partially offset by lower volumes in our trading
	and merchandising business and the benefit of the weaker Brazilian
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	real
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	relative to the U.S. dollar.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	45
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=3,SEQ=46,EFW="2227431",CP="BUNGE LIMITED",DN="1",CHK=140184,FOLIO='45',FILE='DISK134:[15ZCW1.15ZCW15401]DM15401A.;17',USER='WWASSER',CD='24-FEB-2016;18:03' -->
<A NAME="A2227431Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DM15401_1_46">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2227431Z10-K_HTM_BG15401A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gross
	profit was a loss of $41&nbsp;million in 2014, driven by $113&nbsp;million of impairment and related charges related to one of our mills. This compared to a profit of
	$92&nbsp;million in 2013. Improved overall results in our other sugarcane mills were driven by lower costs, higher margins and increased cogeneration volumes. These improvements were more than
	offset by lower results in our sugar trading and distribution business.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;SG&amp;A
	expenses declined 6% to $156&nbsp;million in 2014 from $166&nbsp;million in 2013. Cost reduction initiatives in our sugar milling business and translation benefits from the
	depreciation of the Brazilian
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	real
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	on local currency costs reduced SG&amp;A, but were partially offset by $20&nbsp;million of restructuring costs,
	including costs of our strategic review of the business. SG&amp;A for 2013 included $11&nbsp;million of write-offs and restructuring charges.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Other
	income (expenses)&#151;net was income of $10&nbsp;million compared to nil in 2013. Increased income from our non-consolidated investments in a U.S. bioenergy producer and
	a corn wet milling venture in Argentina that became fully operational in 2014, was partially offset by losses in our joint venture for the production of renewable oils in Brazil.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Segment
	EBIT decreased by $108&nbsp;million to a loss of $168&nbsp;million in 2014 compared to a loss of $60&nbsp;million in 2013. In 2014, segment EBIT included
	$133&nbsp;million of impairment and restructuring charges in our industrial operations. Results from our sugarcane mills improved overall and our bioenergy investments in the U.S. and Argentina also
	reported higher results. These improvements were partly offset by weaker trading and merchandising results and start-up losses in our renewable oils venture in Brazil.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Fertilizer Segment
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#151;Fertilizer segment net sales increased 6% to $474&nbsp;million in 2014 compared to $448&nbsp;million in 2013, primarily due to
	a volume increase of 14% in our Argentine blending and distribution operations, partly offset by lower global nitrogen and phosphate prices.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cost
	of goods sold increased 9% to $413&nbsp;million in 2014 from $379&nbsp;million in 2013, primarily as a result of higher volumes and higher equipment rental costs and spare parts
	write-offs in our Brazil port operations. These increases were partly offset by lower raw material costs and the benefit of the weaker Argentine
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	peso
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	and Brazilian
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	real
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	on local currency costs when translated into U.S. dollars.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Gross
	profit decreased to $61&nbsp;million in 2014 from $69&nbsp;million in 2013. The decrease was primarily driven by higher costs in our Brazilian port operations, partly offset by
	higher volumes and margins in Argentina.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;SG&amp;A
	was $10&nbsp;million in 2014 compared to $34&nbsp;million in 2013. The decrease in 2014 includes the reversal of certain value added tax provisions which are no longer expected
	to be paid and lower general and administrative expenses. In addition, SG&amp;A benefited from a weaker Brazilian
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	real
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	and Argentine
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	peso
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	relative to the
	U.S. dollar.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Segment
	EBIT decreased by $24&nbsp;million to $45&nbsp;million in 2014 from $69&nbsp;million in 2013, primarily due to a $32&nbsp;million gain on the 2013 sale of certain legal
	claims in Brazil, partially offset by a $5&nbsp;million loss in 2013 in our Morocco phosphate joint venture, which was sold in December 2013.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#151;A summary of consolidated interest income and expense for the periods indicated follows:
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest
	income in 2014 increased by $11&nbsp;million compared to 2013, primarily due to higher returns on cash investments in Brazil and Argentina in the first half of the year and
	the collection of
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	46
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=4,SEQ=47,EFW="2227431",CP="BUNGE LIMITED",DN="1",CHK=268268,FOLIO='46',FILE='DISK134:[15ZCW1.15ZCW15401]DM15401A.;17',USER='WWASSER',CD='24-FEB-2016;18:03' -->
<A NAME="A2227431Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DM15401_1_47">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2227431Z10-K_HTM_BG15401A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	$12&nbsp;million
	of accumulated unpaid interest on a loan provided to a related party. Interest expense decreased by 4% compared to last year, primarily due to lower average outstanding debt driven
	by reduced working capital requirements as a result of lower average commodity prices, partly offset by interest charges of $65&nbsp;million related to certain ICMS tax credits in Brazil. Interest
	expenses were reduced due to the refinancing of long-term debt at fixed rates with short-term bank loans, which on average bear lower, floating interest rates. Interest expense includes facility
	commitment fees,
	amortization of deferred financing costs and charges on certain lending transactions, including certain intercompany loans and foreign currency conversions in Brazil.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Income Tax Expense
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#151;In 2014, income tax expense from continuing operations decreased to $249&nbsp;million from $904&nbsp;million in 2013 and the
	effective tax rate in 2014 decreased to 34% compared to 89% in 2013. Income tax expense in 2014 included certain income tax benefits of $102&nbsp;million, primarily $93&nbsp;million of deferred
	tax assets in a subsidiary taxable in Brazil, $21&nbsp;million reversal of an income tax valuation allowance in Europe and $13&nbsp;million from adjustment of provisions upon finalization of a tax
	audit in Europe. Also, included in income tax expense for 2014 is $45&nbsp;million of deferred tax assets which were recognized upon the recording of expenses related to a court ruling related to
	certain ICMS tax credits in Brazil. These items were partly offset by $15&nbsp;million of income tax valuation allowances resulting from management's evaluation of the recoverability of its net
	operating loss carryforwards in Asia-Pacific. Net tax expense for 2013 included tax charges of $512&nbsp;million for income tax valuation allowances, primarily in the Sugar and Bioenergy segment
	from management's evaluation of its net deferred tax assets, primarily net operating loss carryforwards, $46&nbsp;million as a result of new legal precedents that impacted our assessment of an
	uncertain income tax position in Brazil and provisions related to tax years 2008 through 2010.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Discontinued Operations
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#151;Discontinued operations results in 2014 were income of $32&nbsp;million, net of tax, compared to income of
	$97&nbsp;million, net of tax, in 2013. Results in 2014 included benefits related to a tax amnesty program in Brazil and collections of previously written-off farmer receivables. Results in 2013
	represented primarily the gain on the sale of the fertilizer blending and distribution business of $112&nbsp;million, net of tax.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Net Income Attributable to Bunge
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#151;Net income attributable to Bunge for 2014 was $515&nbsp;million compared to $306&nbsp;million for 2013. The
	decrease in total segment EBIT of $373&nbsp;million discussed above was more than offset by the significantly lower income tax expense from continuing operations ($249&nbsp;million in 2014
	compared with $904&nbsp;million in 2013). Income tax expenses in 2014 included net tax benefits of $102&nbsp;million that resulted primarily from the establishment of deferred tax assets related
	to the implementation of certain structural changes in our agribusiness operations. Income tax expense for 2013 included charges of $512&nbsp;million for income tax valuation allowances, primarily
	in our sugar milling business in Brazil. Net income for 2013 also included a $112&nbsp;million after-tax gain on the sale of our fertilizer distribution business in Brazil to Yara for cash of
	$750&nbsp;million. This gain is included in discontinued operations.
</FONT>
</P>
</EFX_RESULTS_OF_OPERATIONS>
<EFX_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL>
<A NAME="FIS_LIQUIDITY_CAPITAL"></A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Liquidity and Capital Resources
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
<UL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Liquidity
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
</UL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our main financial objectives are to prudently manage financial risks, ensure consistent access to liquidity and minimize cost of
	capital in order to efficiently finance our business and maintain balance sheet strength. We generally finance our ongoing operations with cash flows generated from operations, issuance of commercial
	paper, borrowings under various bilateral and syndicated revolving credit facilities, term loans and proceeds from the issuance of senior notes. Acquisitions and long-lived assets are generally
	financed with a combination of equity and long-term debt.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	47
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=5,SEQ=48,EFW="2227431",CP="BUNGE LIMITED",DN="1",CHK=197239,FOLIO='47',FILE='DISK134:[15ZCW1.15ZCW15401]DM15401A.;17',USER='WWASSER',CD='24-FEB-2016;18:03' -->
<A NAME="A2227431Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DM15401_1_48">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2227431Z10-K_HTM_BG15401A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
	current ratio, which is a widely used measure of liquidity and is defined as current assets divided by current liabilities, was 1.49 and 1.50 at December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014,
	respectively.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash and Cash Equivalents
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#151;Cash and cash equivalents were $411&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2015 and $362&nbsp;million at
	December&nbsp;31, 2014. Cash balances are managed in accordance with our investment policy, the objectives of which are to preserve the principal value of our cash assets, maintain a high degree of
	liquidity and deliver competitive returns subject to prevailing market conditions. Cash balances are invested in short-term deposits with highly rated financial institutions and in U.S. government
	securities.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Readily Marketable Inventories ("RMI")
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#151;RMI are agricultural commodity inventories, such as soybeans, soybean meal, soybean oil, corn, wheat, and sugar
	that are readily convertible to cash because of their commodity characteristics, widely available markets and international pricing
	mechanisms. RMI in our Agribusiness segment are reported at fair value and were $3,393&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2015 and $4,125&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2014. Of these
	amounts $2,513&nbsp;million and $2,937&nbsp;million were attributable to merchandising activities at December&nbsp;31, 2015 and December&nbsp;31, 2014, respectively. RMI at fair value in the
	aggregate amount of $110&nbsp;million and $127&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2015 and December&nbsp;31, 2014, respectively, were included in our Edible Oil Products segment inventories.
	The Sugar and Bioenergy segment included sugar RMI of $163&nbsp;million and $157&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2015 and December&nbsp;31, 2014, respectively which can be attributed to our
	trading and merchandising business.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Financing Arrangements and Outstanding Indebtedness
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#151;We conduct most of our financing activities through a centralized financing structure that
	provides the company efficient access to debt and capital markets. This structure includes a master trust, the primary assets of which consist of intercompany loans made to Bunge Limited and its
	subsidiaries. Certain of Bunge Limited's 100% owned finance subsidiaries, Bunge Limited Finance Corp., Bunge Finance Europe&nbsp;B.V. and Bunge Asset Funding Corp., fund the master trust with short
	and long-term debt obtained from third parties, including through our commercial paper program and certain credit facilities, as well as the issuance of senior notes. Borrowings by these finance
	subsidiaries carry full, unconditional guarantees by Bunge Limited.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Revolving Credit Facilities
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#151;At December&nbsp;31, 2015, we had $5,015&nbsp;million of aggregate committed borrowing capacity under our commercial
	paper program and revolving various bilateral and syndicated credit facilities, of which $4,263&nbsp;million was unused and available. The following table summarizes these facilities as of the
	periods presented:
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_19"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;WIDTH:80%;MARGIN-LEFT:10%;">
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
</FONT>
</P>

</TH>

<!-- END OF USER-SPECIFIED TAGGED TABLE -->
<!-- COMMAND=ADD_LINERULETXT,NOSHADE COLOR="#000000" SIZE="1.0PT" WIDTH="26%" ALIGN="LEFT" -->
<HR NOSHADE COLOR="#000000" SIZE="1.0PT" WIDTH="26%" ALIGN="LEFT">
</DIV>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT;MARGIN-LEFT:10%;">
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<SUP>
	(1)
</SUP>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Borrowings
	under the revolving credit facilities that have maturities greater than one year from the date of the consolidated balance sheets
	are classified as long-term debt, consistent with the long-term maturity of the underlying facilities. However, individual borrowings under the revolving credit facilities are generally short-term in
	nature, bear interest at variable rates and can be repaid or renewed as each such individual borrowing matures.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
</DIV>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
	August&nbsp;10, 2015, we entered into an amendment agreement to our unsecured $1,750&nbsp;million syndicated revolving credit facility, dated March&nbsp;17, 2014 (the
	"Facility"). The amendment agreement
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	48
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=6,SEQ=49,EFW="2227431",CP="BUNGE LIMITED",DN="1",CHK=454503,FOLIO='48',FILE='DISK134:[15ZCW1.15ZCW15401]DM15401A.;17',USER='WWASSER',CD='24-FEB-2016;18:03' -->
<A NAME="A2227431Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DM15401_1_49">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2227431Z10-K_HTM_BG15401A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	extends
	the maturity date of the Facility to August&nbsp;10, 2018. We have the option to request an extension of the maturity date of the Facility for two additional one-year periods. Each lender in
	its sole discretion may agree to any such request. The amendment agreement also lowers the range of margin applicable to our borrowings under the Facility. Borrowings under the Facility will bear
	interest at LIBOR plus a margin, which will vary from 0.35% to 1.35% per annum, based on the credit ratings of our senior long-term unsecured debt. We will also pay a fee that varies from 0.10% to
	0.40% per annum, based on the utilization of the Facility. Amounts under the Facility that remain undrawn are subject to a commitment fee payable quarterly in arrears at a rate of 35% of the margin
	specified above, which will vary based on the rating level at each quarterly payment date. We may, from time-to-time, with the consent of the facility agent, request one or more of the existing
	lenders or new lenders to increase the total commitments under the Facility by up to $250&nbsp;million pursuant to an accordion provision. At December&nbsp;31, 2015, we had $277&nbsp;million of
	borrowings outstanding under the Facility.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
	commercial paper program is supported by committed back-up bank credit lines (the "Liquidity Facility") equal to the amount of the commercial paper program provided by lending
	institutions that are required to be rated at least A-1 by Standard&nbsp;&amp; Poor's and P-1 by Moody's Investor Services. The cost of borrowing under the Liquidity Facility would typically be higher
	than the cost of issuance under our commercial paper program. At December&nbsp;31, 2015, there were no borrowings outstanding under
	both the commercial paper program and the Liquidity Facility. The Liquidity Facility is our only revolving credit facility that requires lenders to maintain minimum credit ratings.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
	addition to committed credit facilities, from time-to-time, we, through our financing subsidiaries, enter into bilateral short-term credit lines as necessary based on our financing
	requirements. At December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014, nil and $50&nbsp;million, respectively, were outstanding under these bilateral short-term credit lines.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Short and long-term debt
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#151;Our short and long-term debt increased by $594&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2015 from December&nbsp;31, 2014,
	primarily due to funding additional working capital requirements at year end. For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, our average short and long-term debt outstanding was approximately
	$4,316&nbsp;million compared to approximately $5,372&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, primarily due to lower average working capital financing requirements, driven by
	lower average global commodity prices. Our long-term debt outstanding balance was $3,803&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to $3,263&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2014. The
	following table summarizes our short-term debt activity at December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<A NAME="FIS_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE_20"></A>
<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;WIDTH:73%;MARGIN-LEFT:10%;">
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
</FONT>
</P>

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;On
	November&nbsp;24, 2015, we completed the issuance of an aggregate principal amount sale of $500&nbsp;million of unsecured senior notes bearing interest at 3.50% per annum and
	maturing on November&nbsp;24, 2020. The senior notes were issued by our 100% owned finance subsidiary, Bunge Limited Finance Corp., and are fully and unconditionally guaranteed by Bunge Limited.
	Interest on the senior notes is payable semi-annually in arrears in May and November of each year, commencing on May&nbsp;24, 2016. The net proceeds from this offering of approximately
	$496&nbsp;million after deducting
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	49
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=7,SEQ=50,EFW="2227431",CP="BUNGE LIMITED",DN="1",CHK=556828,FOLIO='49',FILE='DISK134:[15ZCW1.15ZCW15401]DM15401A.;17',USER='WWASSER',CD='24-FEB-2016;18:03' -->
<A NAME="A2227431Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DM15401_1_50">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2227431Z10-K_HTM_BG15401A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	underwriters'
	commissions and offering expenses were used for general corporate purposes, including, but not limited to the repayment of outstanding indebtedness, which includes indebtedness under our
	revolving credit facilities. Debt issuance costs of approximately $4&nbsp;million were paid in conjunction with the issuance of the senior notes and will be amortized to interest expense on a
	straight-line basis over the five-year term of the senior notes.
</FONT>
</P>

<!-- COMMAND=ADD_LINERULETXT,NOSHADE COLOR="#000000" SIZE="1.0PT" WIDTH="26%" ALIGN="LEFT" -->
<HR NOSHADE COLOR="#000000" SIZE="1.0PT" WIDTH="26%" ALIGN="LEFT">
</DIV>
<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT;MARGIN-LEFT:15%;">
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<SUP>
	(1)
</SUP>
</FONT>
</DT>
</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Short-term
	rating applies only to Bunge Asset Funding Corp., the issuer under our commercial paper program.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
</DIV>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
	debt agreements do not have any credit rating downgrade triggers that would accelerate maturity of our debt. However, credit rating downgrades would increase our borrowing costs
	under our syndicated credit facilities and, depending on their severity, could impede our ability to obtain credit facilities or access the capital markets in the future on competitive terms. A
	significant increase in our borrowing costs could impair our ability to compete effectively in our business relative to competitors with higher credit ratings.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
	credit facilities and certain senior notes require us to comply with specified financial covenants, including minimum net worth, minimum current ratio, a maximum debt to
	capitalization ratio and limitations on secured indebtedness. We were in compliance with these covenants as of December&nbsp;31, 2015.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Trade Receivable Securitization Program
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#151;We initially entered into our trade receivable securitization program (the "Program") in June 2011, which
	provides us with an additional source of liquidity. The Program provides funding of up to $700&nbsp;million against receivables sold and terminates on June&nbsp;1, 2016.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At
	December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014, $524&nbsp;million and $599&nbsp;million, respectively, of receivables sold under the Program were derecognized from our consolidated balance
	sheets. Proceeds received in cash related to transfers of receivables under the Program totaled $10,396&nbsp;million and $12,030&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014,
	respectively. In addition, cash collections from customers on receivables previously sold were $10,542&nbsp;million and $12,202&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014,
	respectively. As this is a revolving facility, cash collections from customers are reinvested to fund new receivable sales. Gross receivables sold under the Program for the years ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014 were $10,601&nbsp;million and $12,179&nbsp;million, respectively. These sales resulted in discounts of $5&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
	2015, $7&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and $7&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, which were included in SG&amp;A in the consolidated statements of
	income. Servicing fees under the Program were not significant in any period.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our
	risk of loss following the sale of the trade receivables is limited to the deferred purchase price receivable ("DPP"), which at December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014 had a fair value of
	$79&nbsp;million and $78&nbsp;million, respectively, and is included in other current assets in our consolidated balance sheets (see Note&nbsp;18 to our consolidated financial statements). The
	DPP will be repaid in cash as receivables are collected, generally within 30&nbsp;days. Delinquencies and credit losses on trade receivables sold under the Program during the years ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 and 2013 were insignificant. We have reflected all cash flows under the Program as operating cash flows in the consolidated statements of cash flows for the years ended
	December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest Rate Swap Agreements
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#151;We may use interest rate swaps as hedging instruments and record the swaps at fair value in the consolidated balance
	sheets with changes in fair value recorded contemporaneously in earnings. Additionally, the carrying amount of the associated debt is adjusted
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	51
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>

	&#8203;

</EFX_UNIDENTIFIED_TABLE>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Total
	Bunge shareholders' equity decreased to $6,652&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2015 from $8,690&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2014. The change in equity was primarily
	due to cumulative translation losses of $2,546&nbsp;million, resulting from the devaluation of global currencies relative to the U.S. dollar in 2015, declared dividends to common and preferred
	shareholders of $212&nbsp;million and $34&nbsp;million and treasury
	shares acquired of $300&nbsp;million, respectively, partially offset by net income attributable to Bunge for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 of $791&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Noncontrolling
	interest decreased to $211&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2015 from $244&nbsp;million at December&nbsp;31, 2014 primarily due to return of shareholders capital
	to one of our noncontrolling interests in the United States and the impact of currency translation.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;At
	December&nbsp;31, 2015, we had 6,900,000 4.875% cumulative convertible perpetual preference shares outstanding with an aggregate liquidation preference of $690&nbsp;million. Each
	convertible perpetual preference share has an initial liquidation preference of $100, which will be adjusted for any accumulated and unpaid dividends. The convertible perpetual preference shares carry
	an annual dividend of $4.875 per share payable quarterly. As a result of adjustments made to the initial conversion price because cash dividends paid on Bunge Limited's common shares exceeded certain
	specified thresholds, each convertible perpetual preference share is convertible, at the holder's option, at any time into 1.1331 Bunge Limited common shares, based on the conversion price of $88.2501
	per share, subject to certain additional anti-dilution adjustments (which represents 7,818,390 Bunge Limited common shares at December&nbsp;31, 2015). At any time, if the closing price of our common
	shares equals or exceeds 130% of the conversion price for 20 trading days during any consecutive 30 trading days (including the last trading day of such period), we may elect to cause the convertible
	perpetual preference shares to be automatically converted into Bunge Limited common shares at the then-prevailing conversion price. The convertible perpetual preference shares are not redeemable by us
	at any time.
</FONT>
</P>
<UL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Cash Flows
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
</UL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our cash flow from operations varies depending on, among other items, the market prices and timing of the purchase and sale of our
	inventories. Generally, during periods when commodity prices are rising, our Agribusiness operations require increased use of cash to support working capital to acquire inventories and fund daily
	settlement requirements on exchange traded futures that we use to minimize price risk related to our inventories.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	52
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;2015 Compared to 2014
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#151;In 2015, our cash and cash equivalents increased by $49&nbsp;million
	reflecting the net effect of cash flows from operating, investing and financing activities. For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, our cash and cash equivalents decreased by $380&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash
	provided by our operating activities was $610&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to $1,399&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
	2014. Net cash inflows from operating activities for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 were principally due to net income, including adjustments for non-cash items, partially offset by an
	increase in the use of cash for net operating assets and liabilities. The increase in net operating assets and liabilities is primarily due to increases in secured advances to farmers in South America
	who were motivated to sell their record level crops as the Brazilian
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	real
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	and Argentine
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	peso
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	depreciated
	relative to the U.S. dollar. The net cash provided by operating activities for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 were principally due to net income, including adjustments for non-cash items. The
	decrease in net operating assets and liabilities in 2014 is primarily due to lower working capital levels than at December&nbsp;31, 2013, resulting from, on average, lower global commodity prices,
	which effect was partially offset by the impact of the depreciation from certain currencies including the Brazilian
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	real
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	, Argentine
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	peso
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	, Ukranian
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	hryvnia
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	and the
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	euro
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	relative to the U.S.
	dollar.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Certain
	of our non-U.S. operating subsidiaries are primarily funded with U.S. dollar-denominated debt, while currency risk is hedged with U.S. dollar denominated assets. The functional
	currency of our operating subsidiaries is generally the local currency. Also, certain of our U.S. dollar functional operating subsidiaries outside the United States are partially funded with local
	currency borrowings, while the currency risk is hedged with local currency denominated assets. The financial statements of our subsidiaries are calculated in the functional currency, and when the
	local currency is the functional currency, translated into U.S. dollar. U.S. dollar-denominated loans are remeasured into their respective functional currencies at exchange rates at the applicable
	balance sheet date. Local currency loans are remeasured into U.S. dollar at the exchange rate at the applicable balance sheet date. The resulting gain or loss is included in our consolidated
	statements of income as foreign exchange gains or losses. For the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 and December&nbsp;31, 2014, we recorded foreign exchange gains of $213&nbsp;million and
	$215&nbsp;million, respectively, which were included as adjustments to reconcile net income to cash used for operating activities in the line item "Foreign exchange loss (gain) on debt" in our
	consolidated statements of cash flows. This adjustment is required because the cash flow impacts of these gains or losses are non-cash items and will represent financing activities when the subsidiary
	repays the underlying debt and therefore, have no impact on cash flows from operations.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash
	used for investing activities was $802&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 compared to cash used of $685&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
	2014. During 2015, payments made for capital expenditures of $649&nbsp;million were primarily related to replanting of sugarcane and maintenance and improvements for our industrial sugar business in
	Brazil, upgrade and expansion of an export terminal in the United States, construction of a wheat milling facility in Brazil, the expansion of a port facility in Ukraine and construction of oilseed
	processing plants in Ukraine and in Asia-Pacific. We also acquired Moinho Pacifico, a Brazilian wheat mill and port terminal in Santos, Brazil, Whole Harvest Foods, a U.S. refiner and packager of
	expeller pressed commercial cooking oil and Heartland Harvest,&nbsp;Inc. ("HHI"), a U.S. based producer of die cut pellets for the snack food industry, and the remaining interest in a Spanish
	biodiesel production facility. Settlement of net investment hedges totaled $203&nbsp;million. Proceeds from sales of investment in affiliates included net proceeds of $88&nbsp;million for the sale
	of certain assets in our grain business in Canada to G3 Canada Limited (formerly the Canadian Wheat Board). Capital expenditures in 2015 were $649&nbsp;million, 23% lower compared to
	$839&nbsp;million in 2014, as a result of management's disciplined capital management and generally lower
	capital expenditures in our industrial Sugar and Bioenergy operations in Brazil. Proceeds from and payments for investments for both years 2015 and 2014 included primarily sales of assets in funds in
	our asset management business and the purchases and sales of certain marketable
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	53
</FONT>
</P>

<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	securities
	and other short term investments. Investments in affiliates in 2015 included our payment for our share of G3 Canada Limited (formerly the Canadian Wheat Board) and additional investments in
	SB Oils, our joint venture with Solazyme,&nbsp;Inc. to produce renewable oils in Brazil. Investments in affiliates in 2014 included primarily investments in SB Oils.

</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash
	provided by financing activities was $360&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, compared to cash used for financing activities of $1,058&nbsp;million for the
	year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014. The increase in cash provided by financing activities was primarily due to net borrowings of debt of $882&nbsp;million which were used to fund capital
	expenditures and increased activity in acquisitions of businesses and investments in affiliates. Dividends paid to our common shareholders and holders of our convertible preference shares were
	$241&nbsp;million and $221&nbsp;million, for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015 and 2014, respectively. In connection with our common share repurchase program, in 2015 we purchased 3,871,810
	of our common shares at a cost of $300&nbsp;million and in 2014 we purchased 3,780,987 of our common shares at a cost of $300&nbsp;million. For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014, financing
	activities reflected reduced financing requirements due to a declining global commodity price environment.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;2014 Compared to 2013
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#151;In 2014, our cash and cash equivalents decreased by $380&nbsp;million reflecting the net effect of cash flows from operating,
	investing and financing activities. For the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, our cash and cash equivalents increased by $173&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash
	provided by our operating activities was $1,399&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 compared to $2,225&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
	2013. Net cash inflows from operating activities for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 were principally due to net income, including adjustments for non-cash items. The decrease in net operating
	assets and liabilities is primarily due to lower working capital levels than at December&nbsp;31, 2013, resulting from on average lower global commodity prices, which effect was partially offset by
	the impact of the depreciation from certain currencies, including the Brazilian
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	real
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	, Argentine
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	peso
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	,
	Ukrainian
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	hryvnia
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	and European
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	euro
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	relative to the U.S. dollar. The net cash provided by operating
	activities for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013 resulted from a combination of net income adjusted for non-cash charges and lower average commodity prices during the year. Non-cash charges in
	2013 included an income tax valuation allowance of $464&nbsp;million related to our industrial Sugar and Bioenergy business in Brazil.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Certain
	of our non-U.S. operating subsidiaries are primarily funded with U.S. dollar-denominated debt, while currency risk is hedged with U.S. dollar denominated assets. The functional
	currency of our operations is generally the local currency. Also, certain of our U.S. dollar functional operating subsidiaries outside the United States are partially funded with local currency
	borrowings, while the currency risk is hedged with local currency denominated assets. The financial statements of our subsidiaries are calculated in the functional currency, and when the local
	currency is the functional currency translated into U.S. dollar. U.S. dollar-denominated loans are remeasured into their respective functional currencies at exchange rates at the applicable balance
	sheet date. Local currency loans are remeasured into U.S. dollar at the exchange rate at the applicable balance sheet date. The resulting gain or loss is included in our consolidated statements of
	income as foreign exchange gains or losses. For the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 and December&nbsp;31, 2013, we recorded foreign exchange gains of $215&nbsp;million and $48&nbsp;million,
	respectively, which were included as adjustments to reconcile net income to cash used for operating activities in the line item "Foreign exchange loss (gain) on debt" in our consolidated statements of
	cash flows. This adjustment is required because the cash flow impacts of these gains or losses are recognized as financing activities when the subsidiary repays the underlying debt and therefore, have
	no impact on cash flows from operations.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash
	used for investing activities was $685&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 compared to cash used of $429&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31,
	2013. During 2014, payments were made for capital expenditures of $839&nbsp;million, including investments in sugar cane planting and
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	54
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=12,SEQ=55,EFW="2227431",CP="BUNGE LIMITED",DN="1",CHK=794263,FOLIO='54',FILE='DISK134:[15ZCW1.15ZCW15401]DM15401A.;17',USER='WWASSER',CD='24-FEB-2016;18:03' -->
<A NAME="A2227431Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DM15401_1_55">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2227431Z10-K_HTM_BG15401A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	maintenance
	on mills in our sugar and bioenergy business in Brazil, the construction of a port terminal and a wheat milling facility in Brazil, construction and expansion of edible oil refining and
	packaging facilities in the United States and Mexico, one of our canola processing facilities in Canada and construction of a port facility and oilseed processing plant in Ukraine, an oilseed
	processing plant in Asia and a port facility in Australia. Payments made for capital expenditures in 2014 were lower, compared to $1,042&nbsp;million in 2013, which was driven by management's
	reallocation of capital and generally lower capital expenditures in our industrial Sugar and Bioenergy operations in Brazil, as part of the strategic review of these activities. We also acquired a
	fertilizer plant with port facilities for $24&nbsp;million in Argentina and the assets of a corn flour producer in the United States for $12&nbsp;million, all amounts net of cash acquired. For the
	year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013, cash used for investing activities included cash proceeds of $750&nbsp;million from the sale of our Brazilian fertilizer distribution business to Yara, the sale
	of our 50% ownership interest in our Morocco fertilizer business for $37&nbsp;million and the sale of property from our consolidated investment funds of $48&nbsp;million. In addition, cash used
	for investing activities in 2013 included cash payments for the acquisitions of a wheat milling business in Mexico for $310&nbsp;million, a wheat mill in Brazil for $35&nbsp;million and two
	biodiesel facilities in Europe for $11&nbsp;million, all amounts net of cash acquired. Proceeds from and payments for investments for both the years 2014 and 2013 included primarily the sales of
	assets in funds in our asset management business and the purchases and sales of certain marketable securities and other short-term investments. Investments in affiliates in 2014 included primarily an
	additional investment in SB Oils, our joint venture with Solazyme,&nbsp;Inc. to produce renewable oils in Brazil. Investments in 2013 included primarily investments in SB Oils and a corn wet milling
	and port facility in Argentina.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Cash
	used for financing activities was $1,058&nbsp;million in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2014 compared to $1,565&nbsp;million for the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013. For
	both years, financing activities reflected reduced financing requirements due to a declining global commodity price environment. In connection with our common share repurchase program, in 2014 we
	purchased 3,780,987 of our common shares resulting in a cash outflow of approximately $300&nbsp;million. There were no share repurchases in the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2013.
</FONT>
</P>
<UL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Brazilian Farmer Credit
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
</UL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Background
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#151;We advance funds to farmers, primarily in Brazil, through secured advances to suppliers and prepaid commodity purchase contracts. These
	activities are generally intended to be short-term in nature. The ability of our customers and suppliers to repay these amounts is affected by agricultural economic conditions in the relevant
	geography, which are, in turn, affected by commodity prices, currency exchange rates, crop input costs and crop quality and yields. As a result, these arrangements are typically secured by the
	farmer's crop and, in many cases, the farmer's land and other assets. Upon farmer default, we generally initiate legal proceedings to recover the defaulted amounts. However, the legal recovery process
	through the judicial system is a long-term process, generally spanning a number of years. As a result, once accounts have been submitted to the judicial process for recovery, we may also seek to
	renegotiate certain terms with the defaulting farmer in order to accelerate recovery of amounts owed. In addition, we have tightened our credit policies to reduce exposure to higher risk accounts and
	have increased collateral requirements for certain customers.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Because
	Brazilian farmer credit exposures are denominated in local currency, reported values are impacted by movements in the value of the Brazilian
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	real
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	when translated into U.S. dollars. From December&nbsp;31,
	2014 to December&nbsp;31, 2015, the Brazilian
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	real
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	devalued by approximately 47%, decreasing the reported farmer credit exposure balances when translated into U.S. dollars.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;We
	periodically evaluate the collectability of our trade accounts receivable and record allowances if we determine that collection is doubtful. We base our determination of the allowance
	on analyses of credit quality of individual accounts, considering also the economic and financial condition of the farming industry and other market conditions as well as the value of any collateral
	related to amounts
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	55
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
<!-- ZEQ.=13,SEQ=56,EFW="2227431",CP="BUNGE LIMITED",DN="1",CHK=365185,FOLIO='55',FILE='DISK134:[15ZCW1.15ZCW15401]DM15401A.;17',USER='WWASSER',CD='24-FEB-2016;18:03' -->
<A NAME="A2227431Z10-K_HTM_PAGE_DM15401_1_56">
</A>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<A HREF="#A2227431Z10-K_HTM_BG15401A_MAIN_TOC">
	Table of Contents
</A>
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	owed.
	We continuously review defaulted farmer receivables for impairment on an individual account basis. We consider all accounts in legal collections processes to be defaulted and past due. For such
	accounts, we determine the allowance for uncollectible amounts based on the fair value of the associated collateral, net of estimated costs to sell. For all renegotiated accounts (current and past
	due), we consider changes in farm economic conditions and other market conditions, our historical experience related to renegotiated accounts and the fair value of collateral in determining the
	allowance for doubtful accounts.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<I>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Secured Advances to Suppliers and Prepaid Commodity Contracts
</I>
</FONT>
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&#151;We purchase soybeans through prepaid commodity purchase contracts (advance cash payments
	to suppliers against contractual obligations to deliver specified quantities of soybeans in the future) and secured advances to suppliers (advances to suppliers against commitments to deliver soybeans
	in the future), primarily in Brazil. These financing arrangements are typically secured by the farmer's future crop and mortgages on the farmer's land, buildings and equipment, and are generally
	settled after the farmer's crop is harvested and sold.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Interest
	earned on secured advances to suppliers of $38&nbsp;million, $37&nbsp;million and $32&nbsp;million for the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 and 2013,
	respectively, is included in net sales in the consolidated statements of income.
</FONT>
</P>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;The
	table below shows details of prepaid commodity contracts and secured advances to suppliers outstanding at our Brazilian operations as of the dates indicated. See Notes&nbsp;6 and
	12 of the notes to our consolidated financial statements for more information.
</FONT>
</P>
<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;WIDTH:70%;MARGIN-LEFT:15%;">
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
</FONT>
</P>

	(1)
</SUP>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	Commodities
	delivered by suppliers that are yet to be priced are reflected at prevailing market prices at December&nbsp;31, 2015 and
	December&nbsp;31, 2014, respectively.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
</DIV>
<UL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;;MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
<B>
<I>
<!-- COMMAND=STYLE_ADDED,"MARGIN-LEFT:10.0PT;TEXT-INDENT:-10.0PT;" -->
	Capital Expenditures
</I>
</B>
</FONT>
</P>
</UL>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;Our cash payments made for capital expenditures were $649&nbsp;million, $839&nbsp;million and $1,042&nbsp;million for the years
	ended December&nbsp;31, 2015, 2014 and 2013, respectively. We intend to make capital expenditures of approximately $850&nbsp;million in 2016. Our priorities for 2016 capital expenditures are
	maintenance, safety and environmental programs first (where we expect to use approximately 40% of our funds allocated to capital expenditures), followed by projects enhancing productivity of our
	operations, and growth projects. We intend to fund these capital expenditures primarily with cash flows from operations.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	56
</FONT>
</P>

<!-- COMMAND=ADD_LINERULETXT,NOSHADE COLOR="#000000" SIZE="1.0PT" WIDTH="26%" ALIGN="LEFT" -->
<HR NOSHADE COLOR="#000000" SIZE="1.0PT" WIDTH="26%" ALIGN="LEFT">
</DIV>
</EFX_BALANCE_SHEET>
<DIV STYLE="PADDING:0PT;POSITION:RELATIVE;TEXT-ALIGN:LEFT;MARGIN-LEFT:15%;">
<DL COMPACT>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<SUP>
	(1)
</SUP>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	issued guarantees to certain financial institutions related to debt of certain of our unconsolidated joint ventures. The terms of the
	guarantees are equal to the terms of the related financings which have maturity dates in 2016 through 2022. There are no recourse provisions or collateral that would enable us to recover any amounts
	paid under these guarantees. At December&nbsp;31, 2015, we had no outstanding recorded obligation related to these guarantees.
<BR>
<BR>
</FONT>
</DD>
<DT STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;MARGIN-BOTTOM:-11PT;'>
<FONT SIZE=2>
<SUP>
	(2)
</SUP>
</FONT>
</DT>
<DD STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	We
	issued guarantees to certain financial institutions which are party to certain operating lease arrangements for railcars and barges. These
	guarantees provide for a minimum residual value to be received by the lessor at the conclusion of the lease term. These leases expire at various dates from 2016 through 2020. At December&nbsp;31,
	2015, our recorded obligation related to these guarantees was $5&nbsp;million.
</FONT>
</DD>
</DL>
</DIV>
<P STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;In
	addition, Bunge Limited has provided full and unconditional parent level guarantees of the outstanding indebtedness under certain senior credit facilities and senior notes entered
	into or issued by its 100% owned subsidiaries. At December&nbsp;31, 2015, debt with a carrying amount of $4,081&nbsp;million related to these guarantees is included in our consolidated balance
	sheet. This debt includes the senior notes issued by two of our 100% owned finance subsidiaries, Bunge Limited Finance Corp. and Bunge&nbsp;N.A. Finance&nbsp;L.P. There are no significant
	restrictions on the ability of Bunge Limited Finance Corp., Bunge&nbsp;N.A. Finance&nbsp;L.P. or any other of our subsidiaries to transfer funds to Bunge Limited.
</FONT>
</P>
<P ALIGN="CENTER" STYLE="FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;">
<FONT SIZE=2>
	57
</FONT>
</P>
<HR NOSHADE>
<P STYLE='FONT-FAMILY:TIMES;PAGE-BREAK-BEFORE:ALWAYS'>
</P>
